2.name: Step 1: Instructions
2.value:
Here you can submit an analysis for execution. This analysis makes use of several bioinformatics tools with each tool provided as a separate step in this workflow. As you move from step to step in the form you can alter tool settings to control how the tool performs. Some tools may not have settings or use output from tools that appeared as a previous step. Optional settings may be provided.

Execution of this workflow is supported by Galaxy.

This workflow uses the following tools:

  • FASTQ Groomer (version 1.0.4): convert between various FASTQ quality formats
  • Trimmomatic (version 0.36.4): flexible read trimming tool for Illumina NGS data
  • Fastqc report (version 2.0.0): Evaluate short reads with FastQC software on a single reads file or a paired of untrimmed and trimmed reads files.
  • Bowtie2 (version 2.2.6.2): - map reads against reference genome
  • Flagstat (version 2.0.1): tabulate descriptive stats for BAM datset

extra.description: Reads files that are to be aligned to the reference genome.
This tool formats fastq files so that they can be used by downstream tools

extra.items:
solexa|Solexa
illumina|Illumina 1.3-1.7
sanger|Sanger (recommended)
cssanger|Color Space Sanger

summarize_input|Summarize Input
dont_summarize_input|Do not Summarize Input (faster)

solexa|Solexa
illumina|Illumina 1.3-1.7
sanger|Sanger & Illumina 1.8+
cssanger|Color Space Sanger

25.name: Select FASTQ dataset collection with R1/R2 pair

27.name: Select standard adapter sequences or provide custom?

extra.items:
TruSeq2-SE.fa|TruSeq2 (single-ended, for Illumina GAII)
TruSeq3-SE.fa|TruSeq3 (single-ended, for MiSeq and HiSeq)
TruSeq2-PE.fa|TruSeq2 (paired-ended, for Illumina GAII)
TruSeq3-PE.fa|TruSeq3 (paired-ended, for MiSeq and HiSeq)
TruSeq3-PE-2.fa|TruSeq3 (additional seqs) (paired-ended, for MiSeq and HiSeq)
NexteraPE-PE.fa|Nextera (paired-ended)

29.name: Custom adapter sequences in fasta format

extra.items:
se|Single-end
pair_of_files|Paired-end (two separate input files)
collection|Paired-end (as collection)

30.name: Maximum mismatch count which will still allow a full match to be performed

31.name: How accurate the match between the two 'adapter ligated' reads must be for PE palindrome read alignment

32.name: How accurate the match between any adapter etc. sequence must be against a read

33.name: Minimum length of adapter that needs to be detected (PE specific/palindrome mode)

34.name: Always keep both reads (PE specific/palindrome mode)?

extra.items:
SLIDINGWINDOW|Sliding window trimming (SLIDINGWINDOW)
MINLEN|Drop reads below a specified length (MINLEN)
LEADING|Cut bases off the start of a read, if below a threshold quality (LEADING)
TRAILING|Cut bases off the end of a read, if below a threshold quality (TRAILING)
CROP|Cut the read to a specified length (CROP)
HEADCROP|Cut the specified number of bases from the start of the read (HEADCROP)
AVGQUAL|Drop reads with average quality lower than a specified level (AVGQUAL)
MAXINFO|Trim reads adaptively, balancing read length and error rate to maximise the value of each read (MAXINFO)

36.name: Number of bases to average across

38.name: Minimum length of reads to be kept

39.name: Minimum quality required to keep a base

40.name: Minimum quality required to keep a base

41.name: Number of bases to keep from the start of the read

42.name: Number of bases to remove from the start of the read

43.name: Minimum average quality required to keep a read

extra.description: Compare reads quality before and after trimming.
This input takes untrimmed FASTQ reads.
This input takes trimmed FASTQ reads.

55.name: Step 7: Bowtie2 - map reads against reference genome (Galaxy Version 2.2.6.2)

119.name: Do you want to tweak input options?

extra.items:
--phred33|Input qualities are ASCII chars equal to the Phred quality plus 33. This is also called the "Phred+33" encoding, which is used by the very latest Illumina pipelines (--phred33)
--phred64|Input qualities are ASCII chars equal to the Phred quality plus 64. This is also called the "Phred+64" encoding (--phred64)

127.name: Do you want to tweak alignment options?

130.name: Set a function governing the interval between seed substrings to use during multiseed alignment (see `Multiseed alignment` section of help below). Also see description of this option below in the help section

131.name: Set a function governing the maximum number of ambiguous characters (usually `N`s and/or `.`s) allowed in a read as a function of read length

139.name: Set a function governing the minimum alignment score needed for an alignment to be considered `valid` (i.e. good enough to report)

140.name: Set a function governing the minimum alignment score needed for an alignment to be considered `valid` (i.e. good enough to report)

141.name: Do you want to tweak scoring options?

143.name: Set the maximum (`MX`) and minimum (`MN`) mismatch penalties, both integers

149.name: Do you want to use -a or -k options

extra.items:
no|No, do not set
k|Set -k option and enter -k value
a|Set -a option

151.name: Do you want to tweak effort options?

154.name: Do you want to tweak SAM/BAM Options?

157.name: Do you want to tweak Other Options?

57.name: Is this single or paired library

59.name: Write unaligned reads (in fastq format) to separate file(s)

60.name: Write aligned reads (in fastq format) to separate file(s)

63.name: Write unaligned reads (in fastq format) to separate file(s)

64.name: Write aligned reads (in fastq format) to separate file(s)

66.name: Set the minimum fragment length for valid paired-end alignments

67.name: Set the maximum fragment length for valid paired-end alignments

72.name: Disallow one mate alignment to contain another

75.name: Write unaligned reads (in fastq format) to separate file(s)

76.name: Write aligned reads (in fastq format) to separate file(s)

78.name: Set the minimum fragment length for valid paired-end alignments

79.name: Set the maximum fragment length for valid paired-end alignments

84.name: Disallow one mate alignment to contain another

86.name: Will you select a reference genome from your history or use a built-in index?

extra.items:
indexed|Use a built-in genome index
history|Use a genome from the history and build index

set|Set read groups (SAM/BAM specification)
set_picard|Set read groups (Picard style)
set_id_auto|Automatically assign ID
do_not_set|Do not set

simple|1: Default setting only
full|2: Full parameter list

118.name: Do you want to use presets?

extra.items:
no_presets|No, just use defaults
--very-fast|Very fast end-to-end (--very-fast)
--fast|Fast end-to-end (--fast)
--sensitive|Sensitive end-to-end (--sensitive)
--very-sensitive|Very sensitive end-to-end (--very-sensitive)
--very-fast-local|Very fast local (--very-fast-local)
--fast-local|Fast local (--fast-local)
--sensitive-local|Sensitive local (--sensitive-local)
--very-sensitive-local|Very sensitive local (--very-sensitive-local)

120.name: Skip (i.e. do not align) the first that many reads or pairs in the input

121.name: Align the first that many reads or read pairs from the input (after the -s/--skip reads or pairs have been skipped), then stop

122.name: Trim that many bases from 5' (left) end of each read before alignment

123.name: Trim that many bases from 3' (right) end of each read before alignment

125.name: Convert input qualities from Solexa (which can be negative) to Phred (which can't). This scheme was used in older Illumina GA Pipeline versions (prior to 1.3)

126.name: Quality values are represented in the read input file as space-separated ASCII integers, e.g., 40 40 30 40..., rather than ASCII characters, e.g., II?I.... Integers are treated as being on the Phred quality scale unless --solexa-quals is also specified

128.name: Set the number of mismatches to be allowed in a seed alignment during multiseed alignment (see `Multiseed alignment` section of help below)

129.name: Sets the length of the seed substrings to align during multiseed alignment (see `Multiseed alignment` section of help below)

132.name: Pad dynamic programming problems by that many columns on either side to allow gaps

133.name: Disallow gaps within that many positions of the beginning or end of the read

134.name: When calculating a mismatch penalty, always consider the quality value at the mismatched position to be the highest possible, regardless of the actual value

135.name: Do not attempt to align unpaired reads to the forward (Watson) reference strand

136.name: Do not attempt to align unpaired reads to the reverse (Crick) reference strand

137.name: Prevent searching for 1-mismatch end-to-end alignments before using the multiseed heuristic (see `Multiseed alignment` section of help below)

144.name: Sets penalty for positions where the read, reference, or both, contain an ambiguous character such as `N`

145.name: Set the read gap opening penalty

146.name: Set the read gap extension penalty

147.name: Set the reference gap opening penalty

148.name: Set the reference gap extension penalty

150.name: Searches for at most that many distinct, valid alignments for each read

152.name: Attempt that many consecutive seed extension attempts to `fail` before Bowtie 2 moves on, using the alignments found so far

153.name: Set the maximum number of times Bowtie 2 will `re-seed` reads with repetitive seeds

155.name: Suppress SAM records for reads that failed to align

156.name: Suppress SEQ and QUAL strings for secondary alignments

158.name: Guarantee that output SAM records are printed in an order corresponding to the order of the reads in the original input file

159.name: Use this number as the seed for pseudo-random number generator

160.name: Re-initialize the pseudo-random generator for each read using the current time

161.name: Would you like the output to be a SAM file

162.name: Save the bowtie2 mapping statistics to the history

extra.description: Output descriptive stats for BAM file datasets.
Optional settings for this step is not available.
